15 reasons to come back to Philadelphia, post-pope
After Pope Francis thrilled visitors in Philadelphia, the city is still brimming with energy and excitement. Now it’s the jam-packed, something-for-everybody event calendar that has people buzzing.
The unfortunate few who have never tried a cheesesteak can join locals as they nibble and nosh their way through the first-ever Cheesesteak Festival. The opening of the new One Liberty Observation Deck will inspire the photographer in everyone who views the city from 57 floors high. The returns of the exciting Army-Navy Game and the spectacular Philadelphia International Festival of the Arts bring in the sports and art crowds. Another reason to come back: Cars stay free with the Visit Philly Overnight Hotel Package.
Here are just 15 of the events, openings and exhibitions inspiring return visits this fall and beyond:
New Events & Attractions:
1. Philadelphia’s most famous culinary export gets a celebration worthy of its iconic status during the first-ever Cheesesteak Festival. Hungry fans of the local staple can sate their cravings with samples from more than 40 purveyors, rock out to live entertainment, take a turn on the mechanical bull or zipline and join in other family-friendly activities. October 24 .
2. The Franklin Institute’s longstanding Sports Challenge is undergoing a $3.1 million redesign to emerge as SportsZone. The 3,600-square-foot permanent exhibition delves into the science of sports while celebrating Philadelphia’s love of sports and its teams. Twenty-one new interactive experiences—running tests, basketball jumps, races with virtual athletes—spotlight the correlation between the science of the human body, laws of motion and sports. Opens October 24 .
3. Over-the-rooftop views are the stunning highlight of One Liberty Observation Deck. From high atop the 57 th floor of One Liberty Place, visitors will be gobsmacked by the 360-degree landscapes that stretch for miles. Audio relays stories of Philadelphia’s past and its evolution to becoming a major American city. OpensNovember 2015.
Triumphant Returns:
4. There’s football, and then there’s the Army-Navy Game. The gridiron action, the pomp and ceremony and the long-standing rivalry make for one of the most eagerly anticipated sporting events of the season. Philadelphia has hosted the event more than any other city due to its history—the Army, Navy and Marines were first established in Philly—and the fact that it’s halfway between West Point and Annapolis. December 12, 2015 .
5. For more than two weeks, some of the world’s most innovative arts organizations and the city’s renowned performing arts groups surprise and delight audiences during the Philadelphia International Festival of the Arts (PIFA). Curated by the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts, the extravaganza kicks off with a visually stunning performance using fire and sand to tell the story of immigrants around the world. The citywide festival features dozens of events, a street fair and a large installation at the Kimmel Center. April 8-23, 2016 .
Travel-Worthy Exhibitions:
6. When Alice began her fantastical journey 150 years ago, the world rushed to follow her adventures in wonderland. The Rosenbach of the Free Library of Philadelphia celebrates the sesquicentennial of the surreal tale with Down the Rabbit Hole: Celebrating 150 Years of Alice in Wonderland,a host of exhibitions and programs that explore the literary classic. October 14, 2015-May 15, 2016 .
7. In an unusual match-up of artists, the Philadelphia Museum of Artweaves together Audubon’s classic hand-colored engravings, Hartnett’s magical trompe l’oeils, Warhol’s humorous pop art and other masters of still life in one exhibition. Featuring oil paintings, watercolors and works in other media, Audubon to Warhol: The Art of American Still Life displays more than 100 masterpieces, some rarely seen, drawn from private and public collections across the country. October 27, 2015-January 10, 2016 .
8. For Procession: The Art of Norman Lewis, the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts displays 90 works by the African-American painter, scholar and teacher dating from the early 1930s to the late 1970s. It is the first artist’s first retrospective, and The Guardian asserts that the show “should go a long way to repositioning Lewis in the canon of American postwar innovators.” November 13, 2015-April 3, 2016 .
9. The Golden Age of King Midas makes its exclusive world premiere at thePenn Museum.Therare art and artifacts on loan from the Republic of Turkey include items found in his father’s tomb, excavated from King Midas’ ancient city of Gordion. February 13-November 27, 2016 .
10. Picasso: The Great War, Experimentation and Change makes its first stop at theBarnes Foundation.Inspired by the Columbus Museum of Art’s Still Life with Compote and Glass (1914-15) and the Barnes’ extensive Picasso holdings, the exhibitionfeatures 50 works by Pablo Picasso completed between 1912 and 1924, along with 15 other important canvases by Picasso’s contemporaries. It highlights the tumultuous years of the First World War, when Pablo Picasso began to alternate between cubist and classical forms. February 21-May 9, 2016 .
Annual Celebrations:
11. The holiday season arrives with the annual 6abc Dunkin’ Donuts Thanksgiving Day Parade along the Benjamin Franklin Parkway. Celebrating its 96th year, the 1.4-mile spectacle is the oldest Thanksgiving Day Parade in the country, and it continues to dazzle onlookers with massive balloons, eye-catching floats, festive music, entertaining performances and visits from Santa. November 26 .
12. With Penn’s Landing’s Blue Cross RiverRink Winterfest, the outdoors is a hotspot this winter.The pop-up garden returns for its third year with cozy fire pits, fresh-air eats and drinks, live entertainment and The Lodge Restaurant and Bar fashioned from recycled shipping containers. An immersive light experience surrounds the outdoor rink and wows skaters and spectators. Plus, special events and activities are on tap throughout the season. November 27, 2015-February 28, 2016 . 101 S.
13. There’s only one way to start the New Year, and that’s the Mummers Parade. During this only-in-Philadelphia spectacle, thousands of sequined, feathered, bedazzled marchers and string bands delight crowds with their costumes and street performances. January 1, 2016 .Broad Street between Market Street & Washington Avenue, phillymummers.com
14. It’s time to pop the hood, kick the tires and check out the hottest, shiniest new vehicles of 2016. The Philadelphia Auto Show, the annualshowcase of gleaming chrome and heavy-duty horsepower at the Pennsylvania Convention Center, introduces car lovers to hundreds of exotic luxury,pre-production, concept and model carsfrom dozens of manufacturers. January 30-February 7, 2016 .
15. The Philadelphia Flower Show bursts through the Pennsylvania Convention Center with magnificent displays of brilliant color and design, live entertainment, how-to gardening workshops, and themed activity nights. The world’soldest and largest indoor flower show celebrates a special centennial anniversary with its 2016 theme, Explore America: 100 Years of the National Park Service.
BONUS: Looking Ahead:
The Democratic Party plans to make history next summer when they nominate their presidential candidate at the Democratic National Convention (DNC) in Philadelphia. The city is used to being in the political spotlight: It hosted the DNC in 1936 and 1948 and the RNC in 1856 (the first), 1872, 1900, 1940, 1948 and 2000. July 25-28, 2016 . phldnc.org
VISIT PHILADELPHIA ® makes Philadelphia and The Countryside ® a premier destination through marketing and image building that increases the number of visitors, the number of nights they stay and the number of things they do in the five-county area.
On Greater Philadelphia’s official visitor website and blog, visitphilly.com and uwishunu.com, visitors can explore things to do, upcoming events, themed itineraries and hotel packages. Compelling photography and videos, interactive maps and detailed visitor information make the sites effective trip-planning tools. Along with Visit Philly social media channels, the online platforms communicate directly with consumers. Travelers can also call and stop into the Independence Visitor Center for additional information and tickets.
